Travelers in the Northeast are facing delays and cancellations just in time for the July 4th holiday weekend. Airlines and regulators are bickering about who is to blame, with airlines attributing the problems to the weather and the FAA. The busiest day of the period is expected to be Thursday, with over 52,000 flights, but travelers have already reported long delays and difficulty rebooking canceled flights. United Airlines, JetBlue Airways, Endeavor Air, and Republic Airways have all reported substantial cancellations. United's CEO has blamed the FAA for the issues, saying that they "frankly failed us this weekend." The FAA has denied any air traffic control staffing issues, but has acknowledged that thunderstorms along the East Coast have caused a domino effect of issues.

  2. More than four million Americans are expected to fly this holiday period, according to the AAA.
  3. Airlines are blaming the FAA for the thousands of canceled flights and tens of thousands of flight delays nationwide this week.
  4. Of the approximately 4,500 flights canceled nationwide on Monday and Tuesday, more than 30 percent were operated by United Airlines.
  5. The FAA has denied having any air traffic control staffing issues along the East Coast on Monday or Tuesday.

"It's like a traffic jam on the highway during the holidays: travelers are stuck in long delays, airlines are pointing fingers at the authorities, and United Airlines is the worst affected."
